title: FAQ
text:
Can I apply to the masterclass?
Any student enrolled in the MPhil in Southern Urbanism or in the Mphil Critical Urbanism are encouraged to apply. Have a look at the program!
If you are not enrolled to these programs, you can reach out to explain your motivation and interests.
How many seats are available?
The masterclass can host about 10 students from UCT.
What is expected from me if I join?
We expect you to join the masterclass with lots of questions and motivations, collaborate with students coming from France and Nigeria, and participate during the entire duration of the program. Arrangements have already been made with your MPhil directors to facilitate your presence in terms of schedule.
Funding for transport will be provided during the duration of the fieldwork. You will be also welcome to spend time with the other participants at our guest house in Gardens.
But Friday 7th is a public holiday?
We are aware of it, but to make the most of this masterclass, we expect you to participate this Friday and the following Saturday until mid-afternoon. Sunday 9th and Monday 10th remain days off.

title: Overview
text:
Welcome to the International Masterclass on “Digital Technologies in the African city”!
This event is co-organised by the Department of Geography from the Ecole normale supérieure, the African Centre for Cities at the University of Cape Town, and the IFRA-Nigeria, with the financial support of the Translitterae program.
The masterclass will gather 20 graduate enrolled in Nigeria, France and South Africa for 8 days of conferences, workshops and fieldwork to question and research how digital technologies, from data centres to smartphone apps, reshape urban economies and daily livelihoods, within and beyond Cape Town.
The masterclass will take place on the UCT campus from April 3rd to April 12th 2023.

Application from UCT students
UCT students interested in attending the masterclass can consult the FAQ and send their application to julien.migozzi[@]ouce.ox.ac.uk and laura.nkula[@]uct.ac.za.

text:
Participants
To be announced soon.







At the University of Cologne in Germany, June Gbadamosi is a Coimbra Group Fellow. She is a research fellow with IFRA and a PhD candidate at the University of Ibadan. Her research interests lie at the intersection of digital cultural identities, media, and African Studies. Her current research focuses on Nigeria and examines how digital indentures are changing cultural and digital environments.










Lateef Aremu is a PhD scholar at the department of political science, university of Ibadan, Nigeria. His research interest are in Urban violence and politics of identity.




Acknowledgments
This masterclass was designed with the help and guidance of Liza Cirolia, Laura Nkula-Wenz, Andrea Pollio & Anna Selmeczi.

title: Schedule
text:
After three days of guest lectures and collective fieldwork, participants will decide to work on one of the 4 research topics proposed by the organizers. Participants will then design a collective research protocol, working in small groups for the rest of the masterclass, under the supervision of organizers and research assistants.
Please note that this program is preliminary and will be finalized ahead of the masterclass to take into account the availability of guest speakers.
